review_title: RUN AWAY! THIS SCHOOL IS A SCAM AND FULL OF 1940s PREJUDICE
pros: you get paid You learn what true toxic culture is like so you can sniff it our in future jobs
cons: BIPOCs that are american born PLEASE STAY AWAY. You will NOT be welcomed! They only like BIPOCs that are considered immigrants due to their ignorant view and perception that that demographic is easier to manipulate and revers non- BIPOCs as superior. I only lasted a month here and I knew right from the interview that it was going to be a toxic work environment but I needed money so I could hold out for a better offer. Heres my experience. I worked in their tech department and there was so much gross negligence surrounding security and hazards just one misstep away from causing a fire that it was a wonder that the building was still standing. Speaking of the building, the meeting rooms are poorly made and have no privacy. You could easily hear conversations from every room and I once heard a person reciting their credit card information despite them WHISPERING. The facilities ( theyre are 3 in total ) give off the VENEER of a well-maintained business but the foundation shows how cheaply made and hazardous it is. Which I find to be a symbolic representation of its staff. They present well but are just rotten and prejudiced. None of the staff are qualified to be teaching and the company itself is a scam which is why the student demographic consists of immigrants because they are unfortunately one the most vulnerable demographic in the US suspectible to finance scams and least likely to get retribution for it due to some,if not most of them not holding US citizen status. So deplorable. and the old dust bags in the executive board know this and are just waiting the days away so they can retire with the money they have garnered by feeding these poor students the false promises of a better future. If you are a black person or BIPOC that knows your worth you will be harassed and bullied high school courtyard style to be pushed out to quit so that you cant be fired. And you will be gaslit by other members within the different teams to have them join in on it so you can believe youre doing something wrong when the reality of it is. is that youre not with putting up a charade that white is right and acting inferior to your white colleagues. The tech team is highly prejudiced with how they provide support. they cater to the white staff and students first and treat the BIPOCs as an afterthought. The head of the tech team is super creepy and NO ONE like them and simply tolerates them because of their position. Theyre a coward who will work remotely just to avoid their responsibilities onsite and simply have their other white colleague handle it in their place. So sad. Im glad i got out on my own terms when i did and get this they tried to short me on my last check but luckily i took screenshots of all the time i worked and work I did to rightfully threaten them with a lawsuit if they didnt give me what they owed. so make sure you keep a paper trail of all of your work. Those who remain in this company long-term are ALL COMPLICIT as the act of Silence is not merely complacency; it is an endorsement of racism.

job_title: Career Development Advisor in Cambridge, MA
pros: The best part of my time at Hult was the friendships I made while there. I have lifelong friends that I met while an employee, and have some great memories of our time there. The office space is aesthetically beautiful - great part of the city, relatively accessible, and beautiful space to spend your day working. Access to EF buidling and ammenities is great, especially earlier on in your career. 25% match of 401k is unheard of, and a major benefit to take advantage of. Read the fine print, because it's not vested until several years in.
cons:
Unless you're ready to 'drink the kool-aid', you will likely struggle to advance in this company. A vast majority of employees are underpaid and typically do not stay long once they learn how much they'd earn in the same role elsewhere. 

Hult/EF seems to recruit young, early-career professionals and entices them with perks like an on-campus bar and restaurant, international travel opportunities, and a beautiful office space. But make no mistake - you are entirely replaceable and your unique skills and attributes do not matter to senior leadership. 

If you are considering Hult, always remember that interviews are a 2-way street. You are evaluating Hult as much as they are evaluating you. Ask hard questions and ensure you get the answers you need. If you come across this review and my words give you pause - good. Think long and hard about if this is the right place for you and your career ... there are 40+ higher ed institutions in Boston, so be sure you compare Hult against them before being swayed by their bright and shiny recruitment strategies.

I HIGHLY recommend reaching out to former staff members on LinkedIn if you are in the final stages of an interview for a role they previously held. This will give you invalueable insights that you would not otherwise learn in the interview process. I can almost guarantee a majority of previous staff would happily share their experiences with you, good and bad.

No human resources department to bring your grievances to or help mediate difficult / unfair situations. This is a private family owned company. You are on your own to defend yourself.

review_title: Wish I could have stayed with the company
job_title: Housing Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Working with a 95%+ international student body is enriching and collaborating with colleagues in 5 worldwide campuses is unique and bolsters your communication skills. The staff is very racially, culturally, and nationally diverse and is LGBTQ friendly. I found coworkers to be willing to help each other out though the faculty felt very siloed from everyone else. The school has similar perks to its parent company (EF) with a great amount of opportunity to try new positions and move up if you stick around. Health insurance is excellent—less than $70/month for medical and dental which covers a lot.
cons: Around September of 2015 a VP executive management change resulted in dozens of employee departures, layoffs, job consolidation and an overall low staff morale. Micromanaging, a sincere lack of people savvy skills and expectations, and a dramatic shift to cutting costs all from this new management (which resides in London) contributed to this. For example, I was hired around the mid $50k range and my replacement was hired in with similar years of experience at $40k with additional expectations added. If you’re interested in the international aspect, they are not easily persuaded to transfer an employee to the London/Shanghai/Dubai offices. Expect to work more than 40 or 50 hours/week depending on your role.

review_title: Average employee stays 1-2 years. You are either pushed out of the company or have to change jobs before that happens.

Lots of favoritism in Boston and headquarters in London.

review_title: Full-Time means much more than "40 hr/week" FYI
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
-All the perks from EF (insurance pretty good, lots of free food events, networking and mingling, exercise classes, general "fun" young office stuff)
-AMAZING junior staff. Hard working and professional coworkers who sacrifice evenings and weekends to make sure everything happens. 
-You get the opportunity to dabble in all sorts of things. Your role is very fluid, and you will help in events to departments not your own, always. Great facetime with students, too.
cons:
-Those junior staff members? There are too few of these people, forcing them to work even harder. The work for junior staff is considered entry-level, but is difficult, and complex work. A round of applause for those paid too little to work to the bone. Hult dispenses of junior staff at about 2 years, very few make it longer. 
-Lots of requests to work late, weekends, come in super early. Very "all hands on deck"
-Rude students. Paying for tuition doesn't make me your slave, nor does it automatically grant you your degree. But that's just higher ed sometimes. 
-Would love to see upper management not treat their "lower-level" coworkers like dirt. As well, consider respect respecting the space. Some well-high-up people consider the offices of those beneath them like a trashcan. Reflects poorly.

pros: Experience in an culturally diverse office setting, possibility of unlimited commission upon securing interview with prospective students, relaxed atmosphere
cons:
Cold-calling and emailing prospective students from endless lists, little to no opportunity for mixing up workload, shared office with 5+ employees and manager(s) 
After a month or so, after I had attended a Sales meeting with the other Recruitment Coordinators as well as the Admissions Interns and Directors, I had a much clearer understanding of Hult's unique Master Degree and MBA programs, but until then I had had no real connection to even wanting to secure an interview.  I began to feel better once I finally felt some loyalty towards the school but still, hours of telesales is extremely monotonous!!
I had hoped that working this entry-level job at Hult would give me some leverage to secure a higher level, higher-paying job within the company or its affiliate EF (Education First) language schools, but have since realized how much both companies rely on Telesales as their main marketing scheme throughout many levels.

pros:
-Health Insurance
-Beautiful Building
-It's wonderful to work with students.
-There is a few people who genuinely want to do good
cons:
-There's no such thing as a Human Resources department. (How does a company work without one)
-Micromanagers 
-Feedback is not taken into account. 
-Higher management does not work in your best interest. There's pettiness and a clear disregard for other people's culture and background.
-Salaries are ridiculously low 
-Teams are often understaffed making employees do double, sometimes triple the work, without any increase in salary.
-No processes or information transfer
-The main priority is to enroll as much students as they can, students who can barely speak English are accepted at the school, making the experience for qualified students detrimental.
-Enrollment makes promises to the students that they can't keep, deceiving them and then they just leave them to their own once the arrive at school. 
-No room for growth

job_title: Regional Marketing Manager in Miami, FL
pros:
I strongly believe the benefits, experience, and skills a rapid-growing company with the right vision can give you are unparalleled. 

One of the beauties of working for Hult is it is a privately owned company, which means there's practically no bureaucracy, great ideas make it top the top in no time, resulting in a fun/creative place to work at.

Diversity is another big plus. Collaborating with staff from all over the world, may it be through IM platform or flying in for meetings in places like London, Boston, Hong Kong, etc, has to be one of the things I enjoy the most.

Regarding growth, your potential and ability to execute is your only limitation, as during my two years in the company, I have seen talent being exported from regional offices to central offices many times.
cons:
There is no such thing as checking out of the office, but that is just the way business is, and any modern executive will most likely agree.

Changes in top-level strategy can be a frustrating, but there has been visual progress in this area.

review_title: Invigorating and fun environment - Opportunity for Advancement
pros:
The environment is fast-paced and invigorating. Employees encouraged to take ownership of projects and effect change within the organization. 
The staff and students reflect the school's international nature, which creates a really fun and interesting workplace. 
The school has also undergone quite a bit of growth in the last decade, which has lead to a lot of internal opportunities. Management has a good record of promoting from within. For example, I have been promoted to three different positions across two campuses in my 4 years with the organization.
cons:
At times, the growth of the organization outpaces the staffing, particularly on the campus level. This can result in a less than ideal work-life balance. 
The global nature of the organization is an overall positive, but the simple fact that employees and management are all over the world can lead to challenges in communication.

review_title: BEWARE: Your success is dependent on who is your direct manager
job_title: PG Staff Member in Boston, MA
pros:
Diversity of students from around the world.  Great faculty and staff ...but most don't last long.
Decent benefits.
cons:
Unprofessional management behavior  - top down hierarchy, lots of favoritism and name calling at this campus
Non-collaborative and non-supportive environment
Lack of processes and systems
No staff diversity except for the token few
Lack of institutional knowledge due to high turnover
No work life balance. Everything seems to be an emergency and has to be done that day!
Low wages
About 95% of the staff have been working at Hult less than 2 years


There is no human resources function.  They have something called the RED team that masks as HR but most lack any kind of training, and experience in handling their largest asset - the people who work there. If you ask them for any guidance regarding an issue with a particular person, they will NOT keep it in confidence. Go seek outside professional help rather than see someone on the RED team.

review_title: One of the worst places to work
pros: Great for anyone trying to start their career.
cons:
*below market salary
*the company is constantly downgrading, so no one's job is ever secure
*upper management behave like children - constantly going at it with one another and making it known to other employees, willing to throw one another "under the bus" to help their own careers, even if it means attacking the bottom tier.
*the company makes its employees give fake reviews to up their ratings on Glassdoor.
                    *Keeping my position there anonymous as they try to find out who wrote the reviews.
*high expectations for very little compensation
*the students are for the most part terrible as well. A bunch of spoiled rich kids that treat the employees poorly.

review_title: Great coworkers, questionable product and leadership
pros: Very fun and diverse environment - the staff is on the young side and you will be surrounded by bright, enthusiastic, international graduate students.
cons: Because Hult is a for-profit school, there is a definite emphasis on being asked to do more with less, so many positions are overworked and understaffed.  There is also a fly-by-the-seat-of-your-pants mentality as opposed to long-term planning and vision; as a result, ideas pop out of nowhere and must be implemented with little regard to execution.  This puts a lot of pressure on staff to deliver a quality product and meet students' expectations.  As a result, many employees leave within two years.

pros:
-Lots of traveling. If you are young, single, and without kids, this is a great place for you to go , explore the world and have fun. 
-Lots of room for growth if you are willing to not have a life and bleed for the company.
cons:
-Work life balance is non-existent. You travel on weekends, get back on Monday at 6 am from an 8 hour overnight trip, and are expected to be back at work (and be productive) at 10 am. 
-The overall organization is not good. People are bumped up as managers given their sales performance, instead of their leadership skills. Not all sales people are meant to be managers. 
-Turnover rate is 2 years. 
-The company culture circles around being rewarded with drinks. If you are not into drinking, this is not the place for you.

review_title: Great international experience and opportunities to grow!
job_title: Director of Recruitment and Marketing in Miami, FL
pros:
I am a MBA alumni of Hult and I am so proud of it. I participated in some recruiting activities when I was a student. I went back to my home country since I got good job offers but then Hult gave me the opportunity to be part of its recruitment team and I love it! 
- very international environment
- as a manager you have the challenge to deal with many nationalities all the time
- great bonuses and rewards
- young people 
- travels (great chance to discover the world)
- growth opportunities
- talented employees
cons:
- you really have to travel a lot 
- if you want to grow in the company you have to consider reallocate at some point

review_title: Good for experience, but would avoid if possible
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great training, and opportunities to grow within international education or higher education. Lots of movement within the company, so you can move into different departments. Very interesting place to work, very international. Good health insurance and 2/3 weeks of PTO.
cons: Below industry standard for salaries and way below acceptable pay for San Francisco. Very high turnover and employees feel under appreciated and undervalued for their work with the company. As employees have resigned, Hult has not rehired in their departments, leaving a department which was once 3 to 1 employee. Employees are looking elsewhere. Managers have hands tied because decision are made through upper management and not adjusted to each location. While their company may sound good, I would avoid it.

review_title: Its suspicious to fail a student
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: A nice polished concrete floor that they have
cons:
Very toxic studying environment. You have to convince the faulty that you got money to sue them  don't trust anyone. Don't show your weaknesses. Most students that were kicked out were international students and they don't have green card.

Bankers coming in the school upon the school consent and bankers open accounts for students. And the daily expenditure is well disposed to bankers. A statement can tell many things about one person's life quality. You can fake with the clothing but you can fake it with a bad mouth breath. As a student, you've been seen through inside out. Yes we all go for money but come on They are really nice students and innocent people there. Be gentle. We all one day are parents

review_title: Did an on-campus job as a student helping to deliver services to students.
job_title: Student Worker in San Francisco, CA
pros: My schedule was flexible and there was lots to do.  Sometimes work could move quickly once you know which departments to speak to to accomplish certain projects.
cons: The person I was working under was a poor manager.  When I needed to speak with a dean they were very often in long meetings or out of town.  The school's managers pride themselves in having a "start-up culture" but in reality I found the work culture to be surprisingly bureaucratic and bound up in counter intuitive policies, with many questions and problems left in between departments.

review_title: Innovative, new, and exciting approach to international management education
pros: International atmosphere and colleagues, 5 locations around the world, generous benefits and vacation policies, fun work environment with passionate colleagues and diverse student body, great leadership that prioritizes staff development and constant improvement
cons: Fast paced, very quick changes keep you on your toes, must be adaptable. Often a lack of training and you get thrown into the job which can be good and bad. Workload is demanding and many people end up taking on several hats

review_title: They will squeeze you for all you are worth
job_title: Director of Enrollment in Miami, FL
pros:
- Many opportunities to travel around the world
- Young company culture and environment
- Many paid expenses 
- Bonus opportunities
cons:
- Director of Enrollment jobs are purely sales
- You have to achieve sales targets resulting in tons of pressure from managers
- Low employee retention
- Relatively new school with bad reputation so selling programs is dificult
- Low to no compensation for worked weekends and extra hours
- Almost no work life balance

review_title: Run like a Business - no regard for hard work/relationships
pros: I worked at Hult Boston for three years.  When I started, the Dean had vision, built a great team and the Academic staff worked very hard.  We worked long hours, helped students and faculty as much as possible and had fun in a fast paced environment. There is a very lean staff, so you get to experience a lot of different aspects of Academics/events/advising/scheduling, etc.  My experience there really gave me an advantage when I was able to land a better title/position at a different school.
cons: In the last 9 months or so, top management (in London, not even in Boston) fired a handful of really great people in Boston, started moving people around, making decisions with no input from staff who had been there, etc. The new management structure does not care about the employee culture and decisions are made at one man's whim.  Change Management is an absolute joke and they truly don't care if people stay or leave.  Since I gave my notice, there have been almost ten others who have, as well.  There is HUGE pressure around 'student satisfaction' surveys that have no qualitative information in them, and there is no data to support why students scores go up or down.  The staff works extremely hard and are often disregarded.  There is also huge inconsistencies in resources and staff among each campus.  Student quality is average to low and causes a huge strain on the already very lean staff model.  I would not recommend working at Hult any time in the near future.

pros: PROS: The only pro (and reason for the second star) is that you do get the opportunity to have a lot of responsibility and you learn quickly. You have some say in processes within your team and when working with other teams, so you do get experience in a variety of aspects. Good health insurance.
cons:
CONS: First, don't be fooled by the other reviews with 4-5 stars - they are mostly part-time on campus positions that were held by students - not full-time staff.

Compensation is terrible. Salaries can range between 15-30K less than what you would make at another college or university in the same or a similar position. It is the number one complaint from staff and upper management has done nothing about it  - and admitted that they pushed aside bench-marking research on salaries and compensation.

If you aren't good at controlling your own work/life balance, you will quickly become exhausted.  Overworking is encouraged.

Hult in San Francisco is very short staffed. Staff retention is very low at the lower levels with an average stay of 1-2 years. 

Very unprofessional handling of staff and changes. Rumors run wild - even coming from mid-level managers.  It is very easy to see who the favorites are.

The environment is very toxic. Everyone is at high stress and high tension levels all of the time.   There is no staff privacy at all on campus. No staff only rooms other than the kitchen - which is small and generally busy. Offices are crammed and most walls are glass with open door policies with students and no followed office hours. You can definitely tell that there is a line between low level employees and management and that the needs and desires and overall happiness of the staff below the line is not a concern and when concerns are raised it is met with rudeness from C levels.

pros: Everyone is really friendly and ready to help you with stuff. The school is very international so you get to see different cultures and perspectives. You get to meet people from countries that you have barely heard about. This helps you break your stereotype
cons: None per say. Everyone would like to earn more money, but that's a function of the market I guess. Because it is a small school compared to others which are universities, employment opportunities are sort of limited on campus

pros: Team-oriented environment, opportunities to network with international students, great for self-starters/motivators.
cons: Unfortunately this work environment is not a true representation of professionalism or corporate America. It troubles me that so much emphasis is placed on students introduction to the corporate/professional world but they are still coddled and served as though they are customers as opposed to students of business and at Hult the customer is always right. This academic institution must decentralize and separate from controlling parent company EF in order to function properly and unfortunately, at this time each campus is subject to whimsical decisions made by the Hult family based on personal preferences and has a central leadership team with little to no regard for processes and policy on the local level.   This is reflective in the campus leadership and central leadership alike as decisions are made primarily without any input.  EF is an amazing company but due to it's lack of faith, interest and investment in Hult International Business school, the institution is bound to fail.  Staff are spread thin and taken advantage of and there is no definitive pathway to work your way upward if you work hard.  They will always take the easier more cost-effective option.

review_title: Application Manager - Latin America and the Caribbean
pros:
- Entry-level position
- Flexible Schedule 
- Get to interact with the students from all over the region
- The position allows you to innovate the process and be proactive
- Get exposure of the different career opportunities within the university
- You are encourage to always do better and you are allow to execute new ideas
- 360 reviews once a year to understand your strengthens and where are rooms for improvement
cons:
- It could become very routine after a couple of years (2 years top)
- Not international travels to fairs/universities

review_title: Great student job with networking opportunities
job_title: Technology Student Ambassador in San Francisco, CA
pros: Very helpful and accommodating staff (San Francisco), opportunities to work at networking events, manageable workload and modern IT-environment. Information for students - this is a paid position. It is a great student job!
cons: Much of the IT is administrated by an outside company. That makes some requests and at times even troubleshooting difficult.

review_title: Fun perks, but overall bad culture
pros: Fun perks (food, alcohol, expensed outings), relaxed, casual environment, young vibe. Your boss is like a friend.
cons: Like all EF properties, Hult has a lot of title inflation (telemarketers are called "enrollment advisors") and a culture that can be described as cultish. There's a certain EF philosophy and mindset that you're expected to buy into

review_title: If this is your last option, you have no options...
job_title: Middle Management in San Francisco, CA
pros:
-Jr. staff is energetic and often overqualified.
-Good healthcare and vacation benefits
cons:
-Absolutely ridiculous pay scale, massively top heavy (school specific Deans/ED's makes four and five times what Jr. admin staff are paid)
-Business model is to hire young and energetic staff, work them into the ground, and toss them aside after 3 years.
-Zero appreciation for contributions as projects/tasks are completed.  Once your brutally difficult 1 year task is done, bye...
-Culture of finger pointing
-Mistakes are repeated due to relatively short tenure of staff
-Not really a school, more like rich-kid baby sitting.
-Most of the positive reviews on here are written either by student-workers or faculty (both are treated very well).  Third option is that they were written in groups of "leadership training" with global staff watching over the shoulders as they are written (happened at least twice, pay attention to the timestamps...)
-Absurd work/life balance
-Ethical standards of a sewer rat
-No real ability to advance unless you know who's ego to stoke.
-Culture of the company is on a true downward trajectory, was once an alright place to work.
-Studnets are there to party, no actual learning takes place.
-Rampant rumor mill amongst middle and upper management.
-Zero, and I mean absolutely zero respect by global team for any opinion that is not lock-step with their own. 
-Drinking culture is flaunted amongst students and staff.  This has brought up clear ethical violations in the past.  In short, if the best thing about working at an institution is that they get you drunk from time to time, you should probably quit.
-There are no, none, zip, zero admission standards.  Rebranding Recruiting to Enrollment doesn't change a thing (an email went out...).  As the end of the enrollment period nears, the academic requirements vanish.
-EF (Hult's parent company) owns GoEd, which offers student loans to attend only Hult
-How seriously are you going to take a job at a place where the price of tuition decreases to "make your best offer" a week before orientation?  Add to this that GoEd is owned by the same company and "scholarships" mostly go out just before the absolute last minute to the least qualified students and I think you know what type of business you are thinking about working at.

review_title: Disposable work force - Low pay, no future, worked to the bone
pros: You will work with a few amazing people, who will inevitably leave to  get paid better somewhere else for the work that they do. You will also work with mostly unqualified people who are here because they haven't found success anywhere else, so they stay in these low paying roles, with no advancement, no prospects, and eventually they are "promoted" to a new title that is still inaccurate to what their job actually is, but they are rarely promoted in pay.
cons:
"Is it really all about the money?" -  If its about the money for you, its about the  money for me. The management has no idea what its doing from a day to day basis. Central leadership is on a different campus, and they seem to almost purposefully hire people  who have no business being in that position. No leadership skills, no concept of how changes affect their staff (probably because staff doesnt stay around long enough to actually have an opinion). No position comes with a job description or training. They say things like "no plan is the plan!" as a cute way to excuse themselves from taking responsibility for their bad ideas, or the effects their bad ideas have on the brand, students, faculty and staff. The simultaneously claim to be a start up - but then will say they have been around since the 60's. The School and its parent company, EF, seem to be in the real estate business with a side hustle of being a visa mill. The "standards" for the entrance process is practically non existent, as they are focused on sales, not standards. At least 20% of the students at any given time are grossly unqualified to be at the school, but they all seem to be rich enough to afford the school. In most cases these students do a semester or two and then transfer to another school after getting grossly inflated grades.

The school and EF will send out emails offering a discount on $4000 dollar EF branded racing bikes (they own a racing team) while paying their staff criminally low wages in a city like Boston. At the same time during yearly staff meetings they will tell us sheepishly, that no one is getting a raise, but that they have also devoted $10million dollars to adding better bedroom for the 10 people who sign up for the executive education class. They send their sales staff (not admissions, not enrollment, SALES, because that is what they do) on "kick off" trips multiple times a year. When the grossly unqualified sales staff then fails to deliver the next barrel of chum - the rest of the schools employees will get no raises.

So, you could crush it all year, be the model worker, do more than you were asked, meet and exceed your yearly goals, and they will tell you that you arent getting a raise. So if the cost of living increases, and your wages dont...you just took a pay cut.

Have an issue? Talk to HR! Oh wait. They dont have and HR department. They have a single person who lives in Europe who responds to you by saying "Talk to your manager" because she doesnt believe in an HR department. Literally the Scott Pruitt of the HR world. There are no trainings, there is no guidance, there are not KPIs or metrics for success, there is no support. You are on your own

If you are going to work here - never get comfortable. Use it as a hold over for something better. This place will never actually invest in you. Lots of promises that will never be delivered, simply because they cant do that. You can be "Hult" Successful, by sitting at your desk and routinely announcing to the rest of the office "how busy you are" and "how much work your doing" and how you have to "launch an exam", but not actually really do anything of merit. You can be terrible at your job and no one will care, they just want the illusion that things are working, they dont really care because they have no idea what your job or responsibilities are.

When you see problems and try and fix them, they will tell you not to, because that would draw attention to the fact that there is an issue. 

Dont work here, you are definitely are worth more at any other position, at any other location. They average pay difference at any other institution in Boston is about $10-15,000 more, with better benefits, access to free education, time off and a more respectful, nurturing environment. If you are desperate. Sure, take the job, but you should immediately be planning to move on, because they will will never offer you anything but the minimum. This school could, and should, be a better place to work, but they dont care enough to do that...because they are a real estate company, with a side order of a visa mill, moonlighting as an education COMPANY, not school, lead by a gaggle of unqualified business people who live in a different country, speak in an echo chamber and lag 10-15 years behind the competition but think they are on the cutting edge. You cant wash  off that kind of incompetence.

pros:
Best people to work with in the world (seriously, you cannot beat 'Hult people')
Innovative.
Less red tape and bureaucracy than other orgs.
Works to hire, recognize, reward, and retain top talent. 
Beautiful offices.
cons: Not everyone has a great employment experience, however I think that you truly get what you give at Hult.  If you work hard, are humble, passionate, creative and have a true 'nothing is impossible' attitude - you'll be invested in.

pros: Recognize talent & reward hard work. Fast paced and engaging. Room for advancement. Innovative and always looking for ways to do things better.
cons: Fast paced and held accountable for failures even if some out of your control. Growing company sometimes outpaces managements ability to grasp bigger forces at work.

pros: Truly innovative and focused on being a relevant school in this global economy.  Open to change in process and procedure.  Great opportunity to work with colleagues from all over the world.
cons: The structure of the graduate programs (intensive, one year MBA and masters options) requires staff to also work intensively throughout the year.  If you don't manage your own time, it can be hard to find a break.

job_title: Director of Recruiting in Miami, FL
pros: Been working here for a while now and so far, so good! it has been an amazing experience which i think will last a lot more. very happy in every aspect, in terms of perks and personal growth.
cons: Hult is growing a lot and every time we need more people. We have to increase the payroll to cover more ground.

job_title: Head Social Media in Cambridge, MA
pros: Good place to work, as it gives you opportunity to work with large numbers of nationals. Also good pay. Just recently acquired Ashbridge, I guess that translate to more spheres of influence in the educational sector.
cons: Its a competitive environment, so you have to deliver. another thing is due to the timing differences that comes with multinational company such as Hult, you'll have to cope with some schedules that have time constraints

pros:
The school moves fast, changes things frequently.  The administrative and academic teams are all focused on providing students with a solid academic experience. 
Overall a great school, well placed in the global business school rankings, and steadily rising.
cons: The school does not seem to commit to long-term relationships with either administrative or academic staff.

job_title: Student Worker in San Francisco, CA
pros:
I have been working in Hult since past two years .
I love to work over here because of healthy and enthusiastic environment.
cons: In past two years i haven't feel any cons related to Hult. I am very happy to be a part of Hult .

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Lots of responsibilities and room for growth. Lots of cool initiatives and projects. Staff are amazing and a very talented and passionate group of people to work with.
cons: Lots of changes and initiatives with lack of preparation can lead to a lot of scrambling and uncertainty. Puts a lot of focus on student satisfaction, sometimes a bit more than staff satisfaction.

review_title: Great benefits, tough to live on pay
pros: Great benefits, friendly staff, recognized for hard work, laid back work environment
cons: Low pay, lots of expected extra time commitments (events etc...), some staff are openly favored over others

pros: Flexible hours, good pay and a fun work environment. A great place to hone sales skills. Especially if your manager is as good as mine was.
cons: Had some issues in management, lot of turnover and work can get repetitive. Upward mobility seemed somewhat compromised

review_title: Great Work Environment but not very competitive pay
job_title: Applications Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Greatest coworker, lots of team bonding activities, upper management does a great job at communicating with lower management and take feedback. Very innovative business school. Work with a diverse group of people and opportunity to transfer to worldwide offices.
cons: Bad salary. For all you do its not the most competitive salary.

job_title: UG Associate Director of Recruiting in Miami, FL
pros: Travel, activities for staff recreation, international teammates, great for understanding how to approach customers.  Meet amazing people, but they don't usually last long enough.
cons: Low pay, no work-life balance, no direction and bully management.  Shady last minute changes in staff. Hard to tell if you are about to get fired.

pros: Great colleagues, no dress code, laid back work environment
cons: Lower pay, high sales goals, management is never satisfied with your best and the school is always looking to grow too fast and too much which can negate the validity of the academic side.

job_title: Enrollment Coordinator in Coconut Grove, FL
pros: Great position the pay is good you get con communicate with many people globally.
cons: The schedule is very bad basically all day calling from 10AM-7PM

pros: Great international community. Clear communication, chain-of-command and support.
cons: None I can think of right now.

cons: Air quality could be better on the campus. Long hours is expected from most staffers and the pay is not reflecting that

pros: Great place to work if you love the diversity

job_title: Technology Student Ambassador in San Francisco, CA
pros: Its very easy and convenient, you're constantly surrounded by technology and friendly people. A very unique experience that I would highly recommend.
cons: Its very hard to add more work hours or even get a raise. There are no employee benefits, regardless of the quality of your work.

pros: Hours were flexible, and could sometimes add hours if needed. Very laid back work environment.
